questionsNeedingFlag.question_text: A triangular park has a perimeter of 48 metres. Two of its sides are equal in length, each measuring 15 metres. If the area of the park is 108 square metres, what is the height of the triangle when the third side is taken as the base?
questionsNeedingFlag.visual_description: An isosceles triangle with two equal sides labeled 15m each, and a base. A dashed line from the apex perpendicular to the base represents the height (marked with h). The base is labeled 18m.
questionsNeedingFlag.solution:
• First, find the length of the third side (base): Perimeter = 48m, so base = 48 - 15 - 15 = 18 metres
• Use the area formula for triangles: Area = ½ × base × height
• Substitute known values: 108 = ½ × 18 × height
• Simplify: 108 = 9 × height
• Solve for height: height = 108 ÷ 9 = 12 metres
• Therefore, the answer is B because the height of the triangle is 12 metres

questionsNeedingFlag.visual_description: A right-angled triangle representing a sail with the base labeled 4.5 m (horizontal) and the height labeled 8 m (vertical)
questionsNeedingFlag.solution:
• Area of a triangle = ½ × base × height
• Area = ½ × 4.5 × 8
• Area = ½ × 36 = 18 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the triangular sail is 18 m²

questionsNeedingFlag.question_text: A trapezium-shaped window has parallel sides of length 2.4 metres and 1.6 metres. The perpendicular distance between these parallel sides is 1.5 metres. What is the area of the window?
questionsNeedingFlag.visual_description: A trapezium with the top parallel side labeled 1.6 m, the bottom parallel side labeled 2.4 m, and a perpendicular line between them labeled 1.5 m (height)
questionsNeedingFlag.solution:
• Area of trapezium = ½ × (sum of parallel sides) × height
• Area = ½ × (2.4 + 1.6) × 1.5
• Area = ½ × 4.0 × 1.5 = 2.0 × 1.5 = 3.0 m²
• Therefore, the answer is B because the area of the trapezium-shaped window is 3.0 m²
